title: Sir Courtly Nice
text:
Sir Courtly Nice: Or, It Cannot Be is a 1685 <a href="comedy%20play">comedy play</a> by the English writer <a href="John%20Crowne">John Crowne</a>. Rehearsals by the <a href="United%20Company">United Company</a> were underway when the death of <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a> in February led to the closure of all theatres as a mark of respect. The play was eventually staged on 9 May at the <a href="Theatre%20Royal%2C%20Drury%20Lane">Theatre Royal, Drury Lane</a>. It is the tradition of the <a href="Restoration%20Comedy">Restoration Comedy</a>. A popular hit it became a stock part of the repertoire for more than a century, with <a href="Colley%20Cibber">Colley Cibber</a> and <a href="Anne%20Oldfield">Anne Oldfield</a> appearing in a celebrated 1709 revival.
The original cast included <a href="William%20Mountfort">William Mountfort</a> as Sir Courtly, <a href="Cave%20Underhill">Cave Underhill</a> as Hothead, <a href="Thomas%20Gillow">Thomas Gillow</a> as Testimony, <a href="William%20Mountfort">William Mountfort</a> as Lord Beaugard, <a href="Philip%20Griffin">Philip Griffin</a> as Surly, <a href="Anthony%20Leigh">Anthony Leigh</a> as Sir Nicholas Callico and <a href="Elizabeth%20Barry">Elizabeth Barry</a> as Leonora. Crowne made an attempt to balance the politics of the time by creating a Hothead, a hardline <a href="Tory">Tory</a> character to balance out the <a href="Puritan">Puritan</a> <a href="Whigs%20%28British%20political%20party%29">Whig</a> zealot Testimony but the play still revealed the author's underlying support for the Tory position. The published version was dedicated to the <a href="James%20Butler%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Ormond">Duke of Ormonde</a>.
